title: If it smells wrong, stop.
content: Burning coolant, hot brakes, fried wiring — your nose catches danger before your eyes do.

title: If a bolt fights you, it's telling you something.
content: Don't force it. Heat it, soak it, tap it, or rethink the angle.

title: Batteries don't care about your feelings.
content: Treat every battery like it's ready to arc. Remove negative terminal first, reconnect last.

title: Gravity is undefeated.
content: Anything heavy will fall the moment you stop respecting it — hoods, rotors, transmissions, springs.

title: If you drop a tool, step back — not forward.
content: Old-timers learned this after stepping on a falling pry bar or wrench.

title: Lefty loosey, righty tighty — unless it ain't.
content: Some components use reverse threads: fan clutches, some axle nuts, certain suspension parts.

title: If the car just came off the road, it's too hot to touch.
content: Let it cool. Radiators, manifolds, and brake rotors stay hot longer than you think.

title: Springs and tensioned parts are the silent killers.
content: Coil springs, serpentine tensioners, and clutch assemblies can launch tools — or fingers.

title: Never trust a previous mechanic.
content: Always double-check torque, routing, and fastener type. People do wild things.

title: If you're tired, you're dangerous.
content: Mistakes happen when you rush or wrench half-asleep.

title: Things to Look Out For (Across All Vehicle Types)
content: Rust around suspension mounts — catastrophic failure risk. Cracked or swollen brake hoses — they can burst under pressure. Loose or missing wheel fasteners — wheels can walk off. Fuel line seepage or damp spots — fire hazard. Battery corrosion or bulging — risk of acid leaks or explosion. Worn engine/transmission mounts — can cause sudden shifts or binding. Rodent damage to wiring — especially in parked or stored vehicles. Old or brittle vacuum lines — cause stalling, surging, or lean conditions. Loose heat shields or exhaust hangers — can drop or rattle into moving parts. Tire dry rot — even if tread looks good.
